description: Nothing much to say. It just works. Has configurable shortcuts for tab management. And "--drop-down" option allows you to use it quake-style. No need to install "guake" or alike.
summary: Excellent configurable terminal with drop-down support

description:
the namse powerline or nerdfonts mean something to you?
Or are you a custom fonts entusiast in general?
Well in my short experience XFCE terminal is the modern linux terminal that work's better with little effort. Just select the font or check the option system-font when you have your system-wide monospaced font set to a custom font.

The best terminal I've used till the day is iTerm2 (OSX) which I used for years, when moved to back to Linux, couldn't stand Ubuntu terminal, tried Hyper among others, all of them had something that it simply didn't work well, either limited history, missing shortcuts, customization, etc...

Xfce Terminal does everything, it's super lightweight.
The missing star, is simply because nowadays I expect most features to be available through GUI, and to handle shortcuts, I still had to dive into a file and manually adapt the shortcuts.

This amount of command line customization was exactly what I was looking for. I feel like developers let us customize less and less and I really don't like that. The more tweakability the happier I get!
I keep coming back to this emulator because of its simplicity. But that doesn't mean it isn't capable because it is.

summary: Es una elegante terminal con colores y estilos modernos
